title: Chasing Down Leads: Imaging Conductivity Networks in a FinFET Processor
content: The transmission electron microscope (TEM) is the standard tool for high-resolution imaging of semiconductor devices, including modern silicon-based transistors. Contrast in standard TEM primarily shows the physical and compositional structure of devices. Scanning TEM electron beam-induced current (STEM EBIC) imaging, on the other hand, shows electronic structure. EBIC imaging can visualize electric fields [1] and, via recent advances [2], electrical conductivity [3,4] at high resolution [5]. However, sample preparation can be a major challenge as these EBIC contrast modes require two or more electrical connections to the device. For an electron-transparent sample extracted from a modern CPU, for instance, directly contacting the individual terminals of a single transistor is difficult. Here we demonstrate EBIC collection from regions on a device that are nominally isolated. We see a surprisingly intricate conductivity network extending down from the metal layers and up from the substrate/device layer. Connecting to such a network enables STEM EBIC imaging of many transistors in a lamella simultaneously. Thus, it is not necessary to contact the transistors individually.
